It can be obvious from the tests - just as it can be obvious from the
javadoc.

It's a matter of coding style at the end of the day..
I prefer to javadoc all my public API's, and javadoc important notes, that
about it. I rely on tests for the rest...
It becomes very easy to publish the API on a website. Much easier to read
through than trawling through test code, IMHO.
joe

> --- Andy Kriger <kokaku@...> wrote:
> > While generally true, it is often useful to document
> > why a certain
> > implementation decision was made over another. How
> > often do you look at old
> > code or someone else's code and wonder now why did
> > I/they do it that way?
> > This becomes very handy during refactoring efforts
> > where it is easy to
> > forget that a chunk code is there for a specific
> > reason that should be
> > accounted for.
> > 
> 
> ....which should be obvious from the tests. ;)
> 
> -Eric
